thread.title: Woman Sneaks Cat On Flight, Warns Could Bring Plane Down, Fighters Scrambled | International
thread.title_full: Woman Sneaks Cat On Flight, Warns Could Bring Plane Down, Fighters Scrambled | International | News | Qatar Day

author: Stuff
title: Woman Sneaks Cat On Flight, Warns Could Bring Plane Down, Fighters Scrambled | International
text:
US fighter jets were scrambled and an airliner diverted after a European model who snuck a cat on board the flight became unruly.
The passenger, reported by The Denver Post and CBS News to be Czech model Zaneta Hucikova, is now sitting in an immigration detention centre on suspicion of a visa violation.
Reports said the woman had the cat in her purse when she boarded the Condor Airlines Boeing 767 flight from Las Vegas to Frankfurt.
Nothing like having an emergency landing in #Denver on a 12hr flt to #Europe BC of crazy ladies punching stewardessðŸ˜³ pic.twitter.com/Uex0b8tgD5
â€” Dashenka Giraldo (@DashIsabella) August 29, 2015 Cabin crew decided to put the cat in a toilet, at which point the woman became enraged and punched a female flight attendant in the face.
 Passenger Dashenka Giraldo told ABC News : "She said that she was part of the mafia and that the mafia follows her around the world and that she was able to bring the plane down if that needed to be the case if she couldn't see her cat."
Following the threat, the pilot alerted authorities and two F-16 fighter jets were scrambled from Buckley Air Force Base in Colorado.
A Condor Airlines Boeing-767.
The incident happened over Wyoming about 6pm on Friday (local time).
Passenger Fritz Peterson told CBS: "That lady wasn't happy with the crew putting their cat in the lavatory and then everything went wrong. She started screaming and shouting in the back."
Another passenger said: "She looked a little crazy in the mind."
A Condor spokesman said it had not been possible to continue with the flight, so the plane was diverted to Denver International Airport, where it landed safely, escorted by the F-16s. Passengers were put in hotels in Denver for the night, with the flight resuming the next day.
The FBI said it decided the disturbance was a customer service issue, and was not life-threatening. "The airline handled the matter according to their policy for customer service related matters. No arrest was made."
